page.title: 12HARROW WEALD COMMON
page.content: { This is part of the vast "weald" or {woodland,that in medieval times, {would have made travelling northwards {from London very difficult,but in the {18th century a road was cut through, {linking Harrow to Watford. Today,people can enjoy delightful rambles through leafy glades,or amble through pastures where horses graze. A picnic area on the side of the hill,affords lovely views of Harrow and the suburbs of north-west London. { { Old Redding,}the road that winds it's way along the brow of the hill, past a country club, an ancient inn - {"The Case Is Altered",}and the picnic area, derives it's name from the old English word{"ridding",}meaning a {"clearing through woodland".
